DOC.UNK: 650,000 Strike in Belgrade to Protest Austerity Measures
DOC.TEXT: About 650,000 workers staged a brief warning strike Wednesday after the Serbian republic rejected a package of reforms proposed by the country's reformist government headed by Premier Ante Markovic. Laborers in Belgrade, which is both the national and the Serbian capital, stopped working for half an hour to protest the government's austerity measures, the state Tanjug news agency said. Drivers, store assistants and others gathered at their workplaces to read a demand by Belgrade trade unions for easing new austerity measures. The unions said the strike was designed to warn the federal government to pay more attention to ``impoverished people,'' who may find their low standards of living dip even lower with the proposed reforms. Markovic's program calls for a six-month wage freeze and creation of a convertible dinar, along with other unprecedented sweeping economic and political reforms designed to pull Yugoslavia out of its economic slump. The program, which requires approval by the legislature at its current session slated to end later Wednesday, also calls for an end to state subsidies to money-losing companies which may result in laying off of at least 150,000 workers, according to official government sources. Serbia's officially controlled media unanimously condemned the proposed reforms. Filip Grujic, Serbia's vice premier, told the Serbian parliament Tuesday the program will ``drastically imperil the position of the most impoverished people in the entire country.'' All five other constituent republics, however, gave green light to Markovic's proposed reforms and plans for political pluralism in the country. Serbia is calling for short-term measures to curb inflation, such as price freezes. Such price freezes have previously succeeded in holding down consumer costs, but when the restrictions were lifted, inflation soared to record levels. A prolonged dispute between the leaderships of Yugoslavia's constituent republics over the country's political and economic future came to a head in November when the conservative Serbian government broke off all business and political ties with liberal Slovenia.
